JASHAN

Q1)

a) Population mean is 72 sample mean is 3, 6, 3

b) null hypothesis Ho: new relaxation app doesn't reduce the average resting heart rate of regular user

H0: $R_A \neq R_H$
allermative hypothesis H1: new relaxation app reduces the average resting heart rate of regular user

H1: $R_A \neq R_H$
$R_A = R_H$

c) $S_e = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} = \frac{10}{\sqrt{64}} = \frac{50}{4\sqrt{4}} \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2\sqrt{4}} = 5 \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2\sqrt{5}}$

Standard error is the number of $\sigma$-errors (claims) from the baseline to the mean.

d) $z \cdot \text{score} = \frac{72 - 64}{3 - 2} = \frac{2 \cdot \sqrt{4}}{\text{standard}} = \frac{72 - 69}{2 \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}} = \frac{3}{2.5} = \frac{30}{25} = \frac{16}{8} = 1.23$

e) [Graph with two curves labeled 2.5%, 72, 69, 2.5% with two curves labeled 2.5%, 72, 69, 69, 1.5% with two curves labeled 1.5%, 72, 69, 69]

we reject null hypothesis

(Q2)

$$
\begin{array}{l}
p(A) = 200.2 \quad p(S) = 0.2 \quad p(S) = 0.8 \\
p(A|S) = 0.9 \quad p(A|B) = p(B|A) \\
p(\text{os}|S) = 0.05 \quad p(\text{ns}/F) = 0.05 \\
\end{array}
$$

a) Prior is $p(A)$, $p(A) = 20\%$, $p(S) = 20\%$

b) Posterior probability is $p(A/B)$
Posterior probability is the result of the probability which we need to find

C)

$$
p(F|S) = \frac{0.9 \cdot 0.2}{1.8 + 0.05 \cdot 0.8} = \frac{0.9 \cdot 0.2}{1.8 + 0.4} = \frac{1.8}{22} = \frac{10}{22} = \frac{9}{11}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{l}
p(B|A) = 0.9 \quad p(B|A^m) = 0.05 \\
p(A) = 0.2 \quad p(A^m) = 0.8 \\
\end{array}
$$

d) Yes, the posterior probability will be higher than the prior, as the prior is small now it has increased so it will be higher.
